metadata.subject: Scientists create human embryos to make stem cells

relationships.description: Mitalipov led the research team at OHSU
Lanza is chief scientific officer of Advanced Cell Technology

analysis.purpose: To report on a scientific breakthrough in stem cell research and discuss its ethical implications
analysis.significance: First successful creation of human embryos that are genetic copies of living people for stem cell production

concerns: Legal status of reproductive cloning varies by state
Federal regulations needed for therapeutic cloning

notable_quotes: "This is extremely important," Dr. Irving Weissman, a stem cell researcher at Stanford University, said of the new results.
"Some experts are now saying that somatic cell nuclear transfer may be the only way to truly reprogram cells," Lanza said.

The report also raises the specter that, with a high-quality donor egg, a bit of skin, some careful tending in a lab and the womb of a willing surrogate, humans have cracked the biological secret to reproducing themselves.
red_flags: Potential for reproductive cloning despite ethical concerns
Need for standardized egg donor compensation practices

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this scientific news article

illegal_activity.description: This is a news article reporting on scientific research, not first-hand illegal activity

details: Article by Melissa Healy of Los Angeles Times reporting on scientific research

public_knowledge.context: This is a published news article from the Los Angeles Times about a significant scientific breakthrough

analysis.summary: Scientists at Oregon Health & Science University successfully created human embryos that are genetic copies of living people to produce stem cells, a breakthrough that could lead to personalized medical treatments but also raises ethical concerns about human cloning. The research published in Cell journal details methods that could potentially be misused for reproductive cloning, sparking debate about the need for federal regulations. The team successfully created six embryonic stem cell lines using somatic cell nuclear transfer with innovative techniques including caffeine treatment to improve success rates.
